instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck 0.284 mA
threads.message:
Hello, I have a MacBook air 13 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2017. which had liquid damage, I corrected the <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> which was oxidized and the machine started up again, after 10 days it started to show a problem again without turning on, freezing at 0.284 mA, I changed the <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> once which had liquid damage, but did not start working again, remained stuck at 0.284 mA.

measurements taken.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> - 0.0V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.56v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 8.56v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 8.56v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.15v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - not present
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> - not present
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.24v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> - 0.24v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - not present
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.68V
I would like to remind you that the CPU is heating up.

What do you recommend me to do? I'm a little lost on what to check.

threads.title: macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck 0.284 mA
threads.message:
Fist check diode mode to ground on the missing S0 voltages.

As you get 3V3/5V_S=, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> is OK.
Check if <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR> is good.
Also post <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck 0.284 mA
threads.message:
I checked the s0 pins.
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.327
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> - 0.092
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.005

* <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR> has 0 Ohms

* <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> voltages

pin 1 -> 0V - diode 0.327
pin 2 -> NC - OL diode
pin 3 -> 0V - 0.441 diode
pin 4 -> 0V - 0.346 diode
pin 5 -> Ground - diode 0
pin 6 -> 0.829V - 0.324 diode

One more thing, when I referred to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> in the answer above, I would refer to PM_SLP_4_L, I ended up not writing until the end, sorry. follows the voltage of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> 0v

and one more detail now, I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> again and now I only have 2.3V. Returning this information is important because yesterday's measurement was normal, for some reason I don't have normal voltage now.

When I remove the f7140 I have the correct voltage on pin 1 8,59V

I followed the mesh until the <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>, when removing the ppbus voltage it returned to normal.

* <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> voltages after remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> after replacement

pin 1 -> 1,5V
pin 2 -> NC
pin 3 -> 3,2v
pin 4 -> 1,79V
pin 5 -> Ground - diode 0
pin 6 -> 3,3v


my consumption dropped to 0.045mA already disregarding the cable consumption

threads.title: macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck 0.284 mA
threads.message:
How did you get 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> with 0V at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>???
Please, post accurate information from the beginning.

"pin 1 -> 1,5V"
That means <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> is present.
What about <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> level?

threads.title: macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck 0.284 mA
threads.message:
*changing the <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>, I removed a fault that was in ppbusg3h after that I obtained the voltages

*<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> -> 0,062V / diodo 0,386
